lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump, a day after being acquitted in a Senate impeachment trial, used a National Prayer Breakfast on Thursday to lash out at his political opponents, accusing them of being “very dishonest and corrupt people” who are trying to destroy him and the country.

headline: Xiao Long Bao, With or Without Meat
abstract: At 3 Times, on the Lower East Side and near Union Square, the dumpling fillings include a vegetarian cabbage version.
lead_paragraph: At 3 Times, on the Lower East Side and near Union Square, the dumpling fillings include a vegetarian cabbage version.

headline: Balanced Soup Dumplings, and Much More, at 3 Times
abstract: At two Manhattan locations, xiao long bao are neatly pleated and filled with boisterously flavorful ingredients.
lead_paragraph: Gently lift the dumpling, slowly carry it to your spoon, open the skin and then drink the soup. So goes the translation of a Chinese proverb explaining how to eat xiao long bao, the wildly popular dumplings known for their soupy filling. How you choose to get to the soup — by piercing the wrapper or biting off the dumpling’s topknot — is immaterial; it all leads to the same end.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Engagement Ring Costs
abstract: How much do people spend on engagement rings?
lead_paragraph: These graphs, which show how much people spend on engagement rings, appeared elsewhere on NYTimes.com.

headline: As Coronavirus Spreads, Face Mask Makers Go Into Overdrive
keywords: ['Protective Clothing and Gear', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Masks', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: A factory in western France has become an unlikely outpost to help overcome a severe shortage as supplies dry up in China.
lead_paragraph: ANGERS, France — The relentless whir of machines echoing across a cavernous French factory floor this week is an unexpected result of the deadly virus that has nearly paralyzed cities in China and other parts of Asia. The company, Kolmi Hopen, happens to make an item that is suddenly one of the world’s hottest commodities: the medical face mask.

headline: You Seriously Want Me to Go Out With Her?
abstract: A reader has no interest in double dating with her stepdaughter and her married girlfriend.
lead_paragraph: My stepdaughter is in a polyamorous relationship with a married woman. My husband and I are saddened by her choice; we see no happy ending for her. Worse, after losing her job and apartment recently, she gave guardianship of her young daughter to a friend so she could stay close to her girlfriend. My stepdaughter now wants to visit us with her girlfriend. In the past, we’ve refused. But my husband is softening to the idea, so I will go along with him. They want to take us out. But I will not “double date” with these women at restaurants. I plan to keep myself very busy and otherwise engaged during their visit. Am I being too inflexible?

headline: Major League Soccer Reaches a Deal With Its Players
abstract: M.L.S. has been trying to gain respect in world soccer without bankrupting itself. Will a new labor deal with its players help?
lead_paragraph: Major League Soccer and its players announced an agreement in principle on Thursday for a five-year collective bargaining agreement that raises pay and improves working conditions. But whether it will go far enough to enhance the respect M.L.S. carries in the soccer world remains in question.

headline: Taylor Swift’s Next Big Deal Is for Her Songwriting
abstract: The star singer-songwriter is leaving Sony/ATV, the home of her music publishing rights since age 14, for a new agreement with Universal.
lead_paragraph: In recent months, while Taylor Swift was clashing in public with her former record company over control of her early albums, she was quietly plotting a move to consolidate another aspect of her musical empire: her songwriting rights.

headline: China’s Lavish Funds Lured U.S. Scientists. What Did It Get in Return?
keywords: ['Science and Technology', 'Industrial Espionage', 'Intellectual Property', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Research', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: For years, China’s Thousand Talents recruitment plan attracted U.S. scientists with its grants. Investigators now say China used the program to steal sensitive technology.
lead_paragraph: More than a decade into his career as an organic chemist, Jon Antilla found a solution to the grinding task of fund-raising that, increasingly, was squeezing out his time in the laboratory.

headline: Finland Plans to Give All New Parents the Same Leave
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Children and Childhood', 'Family Leaves', 'Women and Girls', 'Parenting', 'Families and Family Life', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The new reforms will give the same amount of leave to both parents, regardless of their gender, a move the government said promotes gender equality and inclusivity.
lead_paragraph: Parents in Finland will be given the same amount of parental leave, regardless of their gender or whether they are a child’s biological parents, the government announced.

headline: Has Your Veterinarian Been Accused of Malpractice? It May Be Tough to Find Out
abstract: Questions. Rapport. License checks. Second opinions. Here are some tips for finding the right veterinarian for you and your animals.
lead_paragraph: The process of finding the right veterinarian for your pet can be daunting.

headline: Trump Hails Acquittal and Lashes Out at His ‘Evil’ and ‘Corrupt’ Opponents
keywords: ['Impeachment', 'Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Speeches and Statements']
abstract: As President Trump renewed his attacks on Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Democrats, his press secretary threatened payback against them.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump and his Republican allies focused on exacting payback against his political opponents on Thursday after his acquittal in his Senate impeachment trial, signaling that the conflict that has consumed Washington for months may only escalate rather than recede.

headline: An Algorithm That Grants Freedom, or Takes It Away
keywords: ['Probation and Parole', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: Across the United States and Europe, software is making probation decisions and predicting whether teens will commit crime. Opponents want more human oversight.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Darnell Gates sat at a long table in a downtown Philadelphia office building. He wore a black T-shirt with “California” in bright yellow letters on the chest. He had never been to the state, but he hoped to visit family there after finishing his probation.

headline: OneWeb Launches 34 Satellites as Astronomers Fear Radio Chatter
keywords: ['Satellites', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Radio Spectrum', 'Telescopes and Observatories', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Private Spaceflight', 'Research']
abstract: Like SpaceX, the company aims to build a constellation of internet satellites, but its orbiters could interfere with telescopes on Earth.
lead_paragraph: The skies are growing crowded.

headline: China Tightens Wuhan Lockdown in ‘Wartime’ Battle With Coronavirus
abstract: With infections doubling every four days and more than 600 deaths, China intensified its response in Wuhan, with house-to-house temperature checks and mass confinements at quarantine centers.
lead_paragraph: WUHAN, China — The Chinese authorities resorted to increasingly extreme measures in Wuhan on Thursday to try to halt the spread of the deadly coronavirus, ordering house-to-house searches, rounding up the sick and warehousing them in enormous quarantine centers.

headline: Chinese Doctor, Silenced After Warning of Outbreak, Dies From Coronavirus
abstract: Dr. Li Wenliang issued a warning about a strange new virus. Then the authorities summoned him for questioning.
lead_paragraph: WUHAN, China —  He was the doctor who tried to sound a warning that a troubling cluster of viral infections in a Chinese province could grow out of control — and was then summoned for a middle-of-the-night reprimand over his candor.

headline: See How the 2020 Democrats Zoomed Into New Hampshire
abstract: Although the results were not finalized two days after the Iowa caucuses, the Democratic presidential candidates were already making their pitch to voters more than 1,000 miles away in New Hampshire.
lead_paragraph: Although the results were not finalized two days after the Iowa caucuses, the Democratic presidential candidates were already making their pitch to voters more than 1,000 miles away in New Hampshire.

headline: Review: From a Veteran Singer to a Newcomer, a Note of Welcome
abstract: Susan Graham sang a Lincoln Center recital the night before Marianne Crebassa made her Met Opera debut.
lead_paragraph: In opera, the drumbeat of time is written on — and in — the body. Vocal cords grow brittle; high notes start to quaver; low tones hollow out. Singers have to retire the roles of their youth, and eventually retire altogether.

headline: Violence Surges in Wake of Trump’s Mideast Plan
abstract: Clashes, shootings and a vehicle attack erupt in the West Bank and Jerusalem, killing Palestinians and wounding Israeli soldiers.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — At least three Palestinians were killed during clashes with Israeli security forces in the West Bank on Wednesday and Thursday, and an Israeli soldier was seriously wounded in a car ramming in Jerusalem overnight, in a surge of violence following the release of the long-awaited — and highly contentious — American plan for Middle East peace.

headline: The Battle for California’s 20 Million Voters Came Early This Year
abstract: And Michael Bloomberg and Bernie Sanders are competing fiercely in places like Fresno, where candidates very rarely go.
lead_paragraph: FRESNO, Calif. — “There’s nothing magical about California,” Michael R. Bloomberg declared after a day flying through the state — or Iowa, for that matter, he added.

headline: ‘Homeland’ Gives the Long War a Long Goodbye
abstract: After a run of ups and downs, the terrorism thriller’s final season sends Carrie and Saul on a peace mission.
lead_paragraph: In the eighth and final season of “Homeland,” the C.I.A. officer Carrie Mathison (Claire Danes) returns to Afghanistan and comes across the child of a contact she dealt with years ago. He’s growing tall now. When she last saw him, he barely came up to her knee.

headline: Senate Report Criticizes Response to Russian Meddling and Blames Partisanship
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: The report from a Republican-led committee said Mitch McConnell was skeptical about a more forceful American response to Russian interference in the 2016 elections.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Partisan divisions and Republican congressional leaders’ reluctance to publicly acknowledge Russian election interference in 2016 contributed to a delayed response by the Obama administration in the midst of the presidential campaign, according to a Senate Intelligence Committee report released Thursday.

headline: Review: 19 Female Composers Start to Mark a Century of Suffrage
abstract: The New York Philharmonic’s multiyear Project 19 initiative began this week with a premiere by Nina C. Young.
lead_paragraph: The New York Philharmonic is essentially taking a pass on the 250th anniversary of Beethoven’s birth. Instead, the orchestra is celebrating another, more relevant anniversary in 2020: the centennial of the ratification of the 19th Amendment, which brought women the right to vote. What better way to do so than to celebrate women composers?

headline: ‘Birds of Prey’ Review: Nihilism for Fun and Profit
abstract: Margot Robbie stars as the cosplay favorite Harley Quinn in a movie that plays at provocation but declines to provoke anything like a thought.
lead_paragraph: A lot of shocking stuff comes out of Harley Quinn’s mouth — maniacal giggles, streams of obscenity, big words to remind you that she has a Ph.D. in psychology, a splash of greenish vomit — but what caught my attention was the line “I voted for Bernie.”

headline: A ‘Disappointed’ Steve Cohen Walks Away From Mets Purchase
abstract: A deal for the current owners to sell control of the team to the hedge fund billionaire fell apart, but the Wilpon family is still looking for a buyer.
lead_paragraph: For two months, many Mets fans have looked forward to seeing their beloved team under new ownership. On Thursday night, however, Steve Cohen, the billionaire hedge fund manager who was negotiating to buy the team, confirmed the deal was dead.

headline: China’s Dominance of 5G Networks Puts U.S. Economic Future at Stake, Barr Warns
keywords: ['5G (Wireless Communications)', 'United States Economy', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Telephones and Telecommunications']
abstract: The attorney general said Chinese companies were winning the fight for the next generation of telecom networks, posing both an economic and national security threat.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Attorney General William P. Barr said Thursday that China’s dominance of 5G telecommunications networks was one of America’s top national security and economic threats, amplifying warnings issued for years by intelligence officials but that President Trump has sometimes undermined.

headline: Leon Rose, an Agent, Is Expected to Be the Next Knicks President
abstract: Rose would be the latest N.B.A. agent to cross over from player representation to team management.
lead_paragraph: Leon Rose, an N.B.A. agent at Creative Artists Agency, will take over as the Knicks’ team president, a person with knowledge of the team’s plans who was not authorized to discuss them publicly said on Thursday. While Rose does not have experience in basketball operations, he has a deep well of connections to star players, including Carmelo Anthony and LeBron James, in his decades as an agent.

headline: How Can I Open Myself Up to New Romantic Relationships?
abstract: “You should not be able to walk away unscathed, which is to say, unchanged,” writes one of our advice columnists.
lead_paragraph: In T’s advice column Culture Therapist, either Ligaya Mishan or Megan O’Grady solves your problems using art. Have a question? Need some comfort? Email us at advice@nytimes.com.

headline: Boeing Refuses to Cooperate With New Inquiry Into Deadly Crash
keywords: ['Boeing 737 Max Groundings and Safety Concerns (2019)', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: Dutch lawmakers are reviewing an investigation into a 2009 accident with striking parallels to the recent 737 Max crashes. U.S. safety officials also declined to participate.
lead_paragraph: Boeing and American safety officials refused to cooperate on Thursday with a new inquiry by Dutch lawmakers into a deadly crash near Amsterdam in 2009 that had striking parallels with two more recent accidents involving the manufacturer’s 737 Max.

headline: Nello Santi, Conductor With His Heart in Italian Opera, Dies at 88
abstract: Mr. Santi, who led hundreds of performances at the Metropolitan Opera, was a renowned interpreter of Puccini and, especially, Verdi.
lead_paragraph: Nello Santi, a conductor who was one of the most authoritative interpreters of Italian opera, especially the works of Giuseppe Verdi, and a podium favorite of singers and orchestra players, died on Thursday at his home in Zurich. He was 88.

headline: He’s in a Cab Franc State of Mind
abstract: Bruce Schneider has been a grower, a producer, a marketer and an innovator. But mostly he’s been a true believer in the potential of one red grape.
lead_paragraph: Tasting one particular sort of wine over the course of many vintages is like reading a series of books by the same author. Their quality may vary, but they will all enlighten.

headline: Key Question in Weinstein Trial: ‘Do You Believe the Women?’
abstract: The defense is focusing on the relationships some of the women maintained with Harvey Weinstein after alleged assaults, presenting a challenge for prosecutors.
lead_paragraph: One woman accused Harvey Weinstein of forcing oral sex on her in his Manhattan apartment, even as she protested. She continued to see him, send friendly messages and seek work from him.

headline: Freeze on Global Entry Enrollment for New Yorkers: What We Know
abstract: How does the suspension affect those currently enrolled, those who have applied and those who want to apply in the future?
lead_paragraph: The Department of Homeland Security said Wednesday that it would temporarily block New Yorkers from enrolling in the Trusted Traveler Programs, including Global Entry, which allow prescreened travelers to bypass lengthy lines at airports and border crossings.

headline: Afghan War Casualty Report: February 2020
abstract: At least 133 pro-government forces and 53 civilians were killed in Afghanistan this month.
lead_paragraph: At least 34 pro-government forces and seven civilians were killed in Afghanistan during the past week. Although American and Taliban officials agreed to a seven-day reduction in violence beginning on Sunday, The Times confirmed 12 separate attacks that resulted in casualties between the start of the temporary truce and Thursday evening. The deadliest attack took place in Balkh Province, where a Taliban red unit attacked a security outpost in Para Barat village of Charkint District, killing five pro-government militia members and two civilians. Four militia members and one civilian were also wounded in the battle. In Sar-i-Pul Province, the Taliban attacked Korak-e-Arabia village security outposts in the provincial capital, killing four security forces and wounding 10 others.

headline: Film Club: ‘Climbing the Shark’s Fin’
abstract: Why do some people risk their lives to achieve a goal?
lead_paragraph: “Climbing the Shark’s Fin" is a seven-minute film that explores what it means to push oneself to the edge of one’s limit. It chronicles three mountain climbers as they attempt one of the most elusive first ascents in the Indian Himalayas, the precarious Shark’s Fin route on Mount Meru. With astonishing camera work, we follow as these climbers strive to reach their goal despite the possible risk of losing fingers, toes — and maybe even their lives.

headline: Climate Change: It’s a Buzzkill for Bumblebees, Study Finds
abstract: Climate change could increase the risk of extinction for the bees, which are already threatened by pesticides and habitat loss.
lead_paragraph: Climate change could increase the risk of extinction for the bees, which are already threatened by pesticides and habitat loss.

headline: For the Irish, Varadkar May Have Won Brexit, but He Lost the War at Home
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Elections', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
abstract: Young, gay and multiracial, the Irish prime minister seemed to embody the new Ireland. But he neglected the domestic audience, which is expected to cast him out on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — From the start, Irish voters were less beguiled than the rest of the world by the novelty of having a young, openly gay, half-Indian man lead their government. Now, as they go to the polls on Saturday, these voters are poised to turn their trail-blazing prime minister, Leo Varadkar, out of power.

headline: Girl, 5, Is Raped on Grounds of U.S. Embassy in India, Police Say
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Sex Crimes', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: The son of a housekeeper who lived in quarters for support staff at the embassy in New Delhi was detained in connection with the assault, officials said.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — A 5-year-old girl was raped by a neighbor on the grounds of the United States Embassy in India’s capital, the police said on Thursday, reviving a debate about sexual violence against women and children in the country.

headline: Oscars 2020 Predictions: Who Will Win Best Picture, Actor and Actress
abstract: Our expert has been closely tracking the awards races all season. Here are the movies and stars he expects to win.
lead_paragraph: As your Oscar-pool guru, I would be remiss in predicting any best-picture winner besides “1917.” The Sam Mendes-directed war movie has taken top honors from both the Producers and Directors guilds as well the director and drama prizes at the Golden Globes, and that’s the sort of awards-season war chest no other contender can compete with. Though it debuted late last year, “1917” is cresting at just the right time: After six weeks of release, it’s made more than $120 million domestically, and it occupied the No. 2 slot at the box office last weekend.

headline: Mitt Romney’s ‘Spartacus’ Moment and Kirk Douglas’s Death

headline: 10 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Crime stories hold our attention for a reason — the promise of plot, the chance of violence, the high moral stakes and stark challenges to social norms, or sometimes just the intellectual fun of trying to solve a good mystery. We bring you a host of such stories this week, both in fiction and in non. The true stuff first: Sanam Maher’s “A Woman Like Her” delves into the phenomenon of honor killings through the story of a Pakistani social media star who was strangled for pushing her culture’s boundaries, while Emma Copley Eisenberg’s “The Third Rainbow Girl” looks at the way a small Appalachian town continues to be haunted by a double murder that took place there decades ago. In fiction, meanwhile, there’s a missing child in India (“Djinn Patrol on the Purple Line”), a White House intern who uncovers a plot to assassinate the president (“Deep State”), a psychiatrist’s creepy new patient (“Mr. Nobody”) and the latest entry in Joe Ide’s IQ series of detective novels (“Hi Five”).

Biden Jr., Republican senators are pressing ahead with their probes into the finances of Mr. Biden’s son, Hunter Biden.

keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Helicopters', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']

headline: I Quit My Bank. Am I Saving the World?
keywords: ['Credit Cards', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Global Warming', 'Corporate Social Responsibility', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions']
abstract: In our dystopian times, it’s too easy to fall into despair. But some day I will live on a donkey sanctuary with Michael B. Jordan.
lead_paragraph: I had a real spring in my step after leaving Chase Bank in December. I didn’t just leave the branch, I left the bank — properly and forever: Closed my account, took my money back, peaced right out of there. I felt like doing that Fred Astaire move where he jumps up and clicks his heels, but I didn’t. I’m kind of a nervous person and there were teenagers close by. I was giddy because I’d finally fulfilled a promise to myself, that I would leave Chase and stop helping them destroy the planet.

headline: What Would a ‘Recanvass’ in Iowa Look Like?
keywords: ['Primaries and Caucuses', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Voting and Voters']

lead_paragraph: Tom Perez, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, demanded on Thursday that Iowa Democrats double-check votes from Monday’s caucuses after a meltdown in reporting results.

headline: When White Women Wanted a Monument to Black ‘Mammies’
abstract: A 1923 fight shows Confederate monuments are about power, not Southern heritage.
lead_paragraph: In 1923, a group of white women wanted to build what they called a “monument to the faithful colored mammies” in Washington. These women, members of the United Daughters of the Confederacy, pressed lawmakers in Congress to introduce a bill. The Senate passed it, but the bill stalled in the House after fierce opposition from black women, including Mary Church Terrell and Hallie Quinn Brown, members of the National Association of Colored Women.

headline: ‘Cane River’ Review: A Lost Treasure of Independent Cinema
abstract: Horace B. Jenkins’s tale of forbidden romance in Louisiana, completed in 1982, opens at last.
lead_paragraph: “Cane River” is the first — and, alas, the only — fictional feature directed by Horace B. Jenkins, who died shortly after completing it in 1982. The film’s rediscovery and restoration, leading to its belated theatrical debut this weekend at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, is a cause for celebration, although with an inevitable note of melancholy. Jenkins, who had worked mainly in documentary and public television (including on “Sesame Street”), was just 42 when he died, and to see this film, in a new 4k restoration that captures its original 35-millimeter beauty, is inevitably to reflect on the career that might have been.

headline: Michelle Phillips: Caribbean Dreamin’

headline: W.H.O. Fights a Pandemic Besides Coronavirus: An ‘Infodemic’
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Social Media', 'Online Advertising', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Medicine and Health', 'your-feed-science']

She works for the World Health Organization and her aim was to assess and stop a global spread — not of the dangerous virus but of hazardous false information.

headline: Review: A ‘Paradise Lost’ More Dutiful Than Divine
abstract: In Tom Dulack’s take on Milton, the devils get the best lines and costumes, while Adam and Eve are a snooze.
lead_paragraph: Where would plays go if they died? I could imagine “A Streetcar Named Desire” frolicking with “Mother Courage” in the Elysian fields, while David Mamet’s recent works would most likely be getting toasty in the underworld.

headline: Hudson Yards Is Coming for Your Soul
abstract: The comedian Conner O’Malley indicts the greed that built Manhattan’s $25 billion corporate fantasia.
lead_paragraph: How does corporate capitalism imagine the human soul? As a nuisance? An opportunity? Collateral damage? A blob of molten plastic to be injected into a minion-­shaped mold? One of the funniest answers to this question comes from the comedian Conner O’Malley, who has built a career playacting the way consumerism warps our spirits. Out on the street, he has recorded dozens of videos in which he plays, basically, capitalism’s hype man — a loudmouthed white dude-bro who is perpetually awed by advertising and luxury goods. He will rush up to anyone who looks rich — men in suits, men driving ostentatious cars — and slather them with over-­the-­top compliments that lean heavily on the word “pimp.” “Oh, hell yeah, pimp!” he shouts into a convertible. When a Hummer stops near him, O’Malley rushes toward its open window: “Man, you’re a job creator, you’re a pimp, you’re an angel, and I love you forever!” His brain seems full of targeted ads. He accosts a businessman on a cellphone: “Dude, what’s up? Maxim Magazine, am I right?” Sometimes O’Malley’s circuitry seems to misfire, but there is no time to stop and think — he will stand in front of a Mustang and chant: “Steroids! Steroids! Steroids!”

headline: Noah Davis Is Gone; His Paintings Continue to Hypnotize
abstract: The first large exhibition of paintings by the young Los Angeles-based artist, who died in 2015, impresses on several fronts at David Zwirner.
lead_paragraph: Art history is full of artists whose careers, cut short by early death, haunt us with their unfulfilled promise. The 20th century is pocked with many such examples, a mere handful of which include Paula Modersohn-Becker (who died at 31); Egon Schiele (28); Bob Thompson (28); Eva Hesse (34); Jean-Michel Basquiat (27).

keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: Rebuffed by the banks, she pressed her fight and her testimony in Congress helped bring about a billion-dollar settlement over accounts of Holocaust victims that were long hidden.

headline: China Begins Testing an Antiviral Drug in Coronavirus Patients
abstract: Patients in a clinical trial will receive a placebo or remdesivir, which has shown promise in laboratory studies.
lead_paragraph: China is forging ahead in the search for treatments for people sickened by the new coronavirus that has infected more than 28,000 people in a countrywide epidemic, killed more than 500 and seeded smaller outbreaks in 24 other nations.

headline: Beyond Architecture, a Builder of Lusty Fantasies
abstract: The Morgan Library & Museum is exhibiting the unleashed imagination of Jean-Jacques Lequeu, who reveled in light and pleasure.
lead_paragraph: In the wake of the 2008 financial crisis, architecture found itself back at the drafting table. Clients got spooked (or went broke), construction rates plummeted in the United States and Europe, and young architects in particular had to find new ways to work. And so this past decade has greeted a welter of digital projects, performances, pop-up designs and “paper architecture,” by practitioners born too late for big budgets.

headline: An Artist Who Collaborates With Her 11-Year-Old Daughter
abstract: Susan Cianciolo’s intuitive, craft-oriented practice has encompassed everything from handmade clothing to an alternative currency.
lead_paragraph: The artist Susan Cianciolo is often inspired to make work by what she describes as visiting spirits. In moments of emotional distress, or after days of strictly disciplined meditation, these otherworldly apparitions appear to her as glowing vermilion orbs, towering humanoids and insects that bolt across the ceiling, all of which she depicts in colorful drawings, paintings and collages. “I don’t know when or how, but at some point I started to physically see things, as real as you are right in front of me,” she says, crouching over a stack of vividly painted canvases that lean against the wall in the narrow hallway of her studio, which occupies the first of two floors she rents in a Fort Greene, Brooklyn, townhouse — the Rhode Island-born Cianciolo lives upstairs with her 11-year-old daughter, Lilac. One of the works in the stack is a self-portrait created last summer during a residency hosted by the Milan gallery Martina Simeti that shows the artist reclining with flushed cheeks, her face clouded by a rosy blot of pink watercolor, and surrounded by floating gemlike cells rendered in vibrant azure blue. “I was seeing all these bugs, so I started studying bugs incessantly and learning all their names in Italian,” she says. “This is how my work goes. I just go on these paths that I don’t even understand.”

headline: Benetton Severs Ties With Oliviero Toscani

abstract: Mr. Sanders vastly outperformed his rivals in the ad hoc Iowa caucuses held in the state, across the nation and around the world. In an extremely tight race, his success in them could prove critical.
lead_paragraph: They caucused in Arizona, in Paris and in the former Soviet republic of Georgia; inside workplaces, on college campuses and at nursing homes; in Spanish and in American Sign Language.

headline: Bloomberg Pursues Wealthy Donors, but Not Their Checkbooks

abstract: We checked misleading statements that President Trump made about his trial, his political enemies and his own record.

headline: The Dog Park Is Bad, Actually
abstract: Dog parks may seem like great additions to the community, but they’re rife with problems — for you, and for your dog. Here’s what to know before you go.
lead_paragraph: Every morning, rain, shine or snow, people stand around making conversation with strangers as their dogs chase, run and mingle. Ranging from elaborate fenced playgrounds and rolling fields to small inner-city runs, dog parks are among the fastest growing park amenities nationwide. The Trust for Public Land found that there has been a 40 percent increase in the development of dog parks since 2009.

headline: A Noted Musician’s Instrument Was Ruined. Not by Us, Says T.S.A.

headline: Minimizing Risk in a Global Panic
abstract: How people living on the outskirts of an epidemic are navigating life.

headline: What’s on TV Friday: ‘Timmy Failure’ and ‘Mythic Quest’
abstract: A family movie from the director Tom McCarthy debuts on Disney Plus. And a new comedy series hits Apple TV Plus.
lead_paragraph: TIMMY FAILURE: MISTAKES WERE MADE (2020) Stream on Disney Plus. The filmmaker Tom McCarthy’s 2015 investigative journalism nail-biter, “Spotlight,” won an Academy Award for best picture. “Timmy Failure,” his first movie since, is also about professional investigators. One of them is an 11-year-old. The other is a polar bear. Based on a series of children’s books by Stephan Pastis (who wrote the screenplay with McCarthy), “Timmy Failure” centers on a boy (Winslow Fegley) who runs a detective business in Portland, Ore., with the help of a big, hairy Arctic escapee. While the movie is skipping theaters in favor of being released directly on Disney’s streaming service, “it owes more to independent cinema than anything,” McCarthy told The New York Times last year. It is both family-oriented and proudly weird.

The book tells the story “virtually to perfection,” Roger Lowenstein wrote here.

headline: I Had a Gloriously Wild Childhood. That’s Why I Wrote ‘How to Train Your Dragon.’
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature', 'Wilderness Areas', 'Global Warming']
abstract: We must give children the opportunity to interact with the wilderness, so that they learn to preserve the natural world.
lead_paragraph: I was 9 years old, hanging on as tightly as I could to my father’s legs as he dangled over the edge of a gigantic sea cliff on a tiny little island off the west coast of Scotland. He was trying to see whether the bird’s nest some 15 feet below was being inhabited by a white-tailed sea eagle or a buzzard.

headline: How an Education Visionary Got Canceled
abstract: Was it a racially dubious blog post? Or did a charter school board seize a chance to get rid of an arrogant autocrat?
lead_paragraph: Last year, on the morning of June 27, hundreds of people filled the gilt-ceilinged Kings Theater in Flatbush for the graduation of Brooklyn Ascend High School’s first senior class. The valedictorian, Chyna Campbell, took the stage and spoke about the value of perseverance.

headline: Mourning My Mom, One Red Carpet at a Time
abstract: The ritual of watching Hollywood awards show coverage helps keep my mom’s voice from fading, if only through the texts I imagine her sending.
lead_paragraph: For most of my adult life, every winter when awards season rolled around I would get primed and ready to have an epic night. Not because I was an Oscar-nominated ingénue about to walk the red carpet in Valentino couture and Bulgari earrings, but because my mom’s red carpet commentary was the stuff of legend. At least, it was on my Facebook page, where I shamelessly posted screenshots of her best emoji-filled texts.

headline: ‘We Are Left to Face Death Alone’
abstract: The Assad regime and its Russian allies are brutally attacking Idlib province in Syria, but the world has abandoned the Syrian people.
lead_paragraph: When the forces of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria destroyed and took control of my city of Aleppo, its residents, including my family, were forced to flee to the northwestern Idlib province. The pattern repeated after every military assault by the Syrian regime on cities and towns outside its control. Idlib became the sanctuary for about four million people.

headline: The Republican Party Has Embraced Its Worst Self
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Constitution (US)', 'Impeachment']
abstract: Trump’s acquittal is a reminder that history doesn’t always move forward. Reaction and retrenchment often triumph.
lead_paragraph: Most Americans have a Whiggish view of their history, in which the story of America is one of gradual moral progress and expanding political liberty — of the nation continuously moving toward a more perfect union. It’s a vision President Barack Obama evoked in his 2015 speech on the 50th anniversary of “Bloody Sunday” in Selma, Ala., even as he tied it to work and struggle. “Two hundred and thirty-nine years after this nation’s founding, our union is not yet perfect,” he said. “But we are getting closer.”

headline: Black Workers’ Wages Are Finally Rising
keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Labor and Jobs', 'United States Economy', 'Vocational Training']
abstract: Their pay is increasing after a decade of stagnation. One man’s story shows the hope — and limitations — with that shift.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — On a brisk January morning Markus Mitchell arrives at his desk at 8:30, his phone ringing before he can even log in to his computer. An employee at the giant nonprofit where Mr. Mitchell works is locked out of the organization’s network and needs the 24-year-old’s help.

headline: A Democratic President Cannot Undo All of Trump’s Damage in 100 Days
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Social Security (US)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'Filibusters and Debate Curbs']
abstract: Instead of pushing to get everything done quickly, a Democrat needs to avoid midterm backlash and focus on the long term.
lead_paragraph: Democrats running for president have been arguing about what they intend to do if elected, but just as significant, about how they would get it done. Achieving policy goals involves either building cross-partisan coalitions in a post-Trump political environment or exercising power more aggressively, shoving aside procedural norms along the way.

headline: How a Champion of Female Filmmakers Spends Her Sundays

abstract: Political rationalization has always been part of politics. But what is happening now is dangerous.

Still, as I watched my former colleagues defend the president during his impeachment trial, I was struck by the same question that baffles many: Why didn’t more Republican senators convict President Trump, or at least allow additional witnesses in his impeachment trial? My conversations with lawmakers, and my own experiences in Congress, offer up a theory.

Xavier Amin Dphrepaulezz, better known as Fantastic Negrito, is an Oakland-based musician who sees himself as a bridge between Oakland’s past and present. From the early days of hip-hop and punk to the city’s current gentrification, he is a true believer in the city’s intoxicating energy.

abstract: Alma Zadic arrived in Vienna from Bosnia when she was 10. Now, she is the justice minister in an awkward coalition of liberal Greens and hard-line, anti-immigrant conservatives.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — Alma Zadic is nervous about standing too close to the row of large windows in her office. Since becoming Austria’s justice minister, the threats have been relentless. “A bullet is reserved for you,” read a recent one. Hours after being sworn in last month, Ms. Zadic was given police protection.

headline: What I Wanted to Say in ‘The Inheritance.’ And What I Didn’t.
abstract: Matthew Lopez on what inspired his two-part play about gay culture in the wake of AIDS, and the limits of “affirmative representation.”
lead_paragraph: Theatergoers of different generations have had passionate responses to “The Inheritance,” Matthew Lopez’s two-part play about gay culture and the legacy of AIDS. The show was celebrated in its original runs in London, but the reception has been more divided on Broadway, both among professional critics and regular attendees. While many have found the show inordinately moving, others have criticized a lack of diversity in the central cast and narrow representation of contemporary gay life. We asked Lopez to write about what inspired the play and to reflect on why some audience members don’t like what they see.

headline: Readers React to ‘The Inheritance’: ‘We Are All Just Humans Looking for a Purpose’
abstract: Did reaction to Matthew Lopez’s award-winning play about gay history vary by generation? We put that question to readers of our theater newsletter.
lead_paragraph: Ben Brantley’s review of “The Inheritance” drew more than 100 comments, signaling the strong reactions engendered by the show. (One reader called the play “pompous, elitist, superficial” and “magnetically entertaining” all at once.) Did the show’s impact vary by generation? We put that question to readers of our theater newsletter. An edited selection of their responses follows. (You can subscribe to the free newsletter here).

And your relationship with that Amazon coat, which seemed so on-trend last winter, has definitely soured. That moment, reader, is upon us.

The official “artist bio” was also mysterious, saying only that Mr. Mock had graduated from ArtCenter College of Design and “lives and works in Los Angeles.”

Once I collected my books — my treasures — I would sneak away, ready to be transported to a new world, a new life.

It’s a powerful use case for the company’s technology, but raises new questions about the tool’s accuracy and how the company handles data.

headline: She Had One Goal Before She Died: Finish That Last Marathon

headline: What to Cook (Grill!) This Weekend
abstract: We may be well into winter, but the call of the grill is powerful for some. (No? It’s not? We have recipes for you, too.)
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I hope you’ll be getting first tracks at Mt. Hood in Oregon this weekend, pushing out of Timberline to hit Thunder to Phlox to Wingle’s Wiggle, then back up Pucci, en route Magic Mile. I hope you’ll greet sunrise at the edge of the Everglades, push down toward the Lostmans River, Watson’s Place, Shadow Country, and cast to rolling tarpon or hidden snook. I hope you’ll get out into Acadia for a few hours if you live Down East, hike the Witch Hole Pond Loop, warm up with some hot chocolate afterward. I hope you’ll end the day at Grandview, in Encinitas, Southern California, ripping swells that developed hundreds of miles to the west.

headline: Roger Kahn, Who Lifted Sportswriting With ‘Boys of Summer,’ Dies at 92
abstract: His 1972 book about his beloved Brooklyn Dodgers, acknowledged as a classic, was, like many of his 20 or so other books, steeped in memories of his boyhood.

headline: ‘The Scream’ Is Fading. New Research Reveals Why.
abstract: The art world is increasingly turning to scientific analysis of pigments to find out how time has changed some famous paintings.
lead_paragraph: “The Scream” is fading. And tiny samples of paint from the 1910 version of Edvard Munch’s famous image of angst have been under the X-ray, the laser beam and even a high-powered electron microscope, as scientists have used cutting-edge technology to try to figure out why portions of the canvas that were a brilliant orangeish-yellow are now an ivory white.

headline: Who Are the Birds of Prey, Exactly? A Guide to Harley Quinn’s Team
abstract: With the movie “Birds of Prey” in theaters, we offer a character explainer.
lead_paragraph: There’s a moment in DC’s “Birds of Prey (and the Fantabulous Emancipation of One Harley Quinn)” you’d never see with the male-dominated teams of the Avengers or the Justice League. Midway through a wild brawl, the bubbly criminal-turned-mercenary Harley Quinn (Margot Robbie) sees her ally Black Canary (Jurnee Smollett-Bell) struggling as her long hair gets in her eyes. Harley slides over and gives her a hair tie, and they get back to knocking down goons. Batman may have a lot in his utility belt, but definitely not a hair tie.

headline: ‘Star Trek: Picard’ Recap: Getting the Band Together
abstract: Jean-Luc officially begins his quest — and looks more comfortable than he did at the vineyard.
lead_paragraph: The first three episodes of “Star Trek: Picard” feel like a long pilot unto themselves. We establish what Picard has been up to. We establish several new characters, the central conflict and the circumstances which led to the conflict; in this case, Picard’s efforts to rescue Romulus from the supernova. By the conclusion of “The End Is the Beginning” — an apt title — we have our central arc: Picard has formed a ragtag group of outsiders to solve this thing on their own.

headline: For a Better Cocktail, Reach for a Different Shaker
abstract: Salt, arguably the most important ingredient in the kitchen, is just as critical at the bar.
lead_paragraph: Often, the goal when making drinks at home is to, well, drink at home. It’s not to try a new technique, buy an obscure bottle you’ll use only a quarter ounce of, or wait 20-plus minutes for a cocktail — that’s what bars are for.

headline: Iman, Charlie Puth and Diplo at amfAR Gala
abstract: And the 60th Annual Quadrille Ball takes place at the Pierre.
lead_paragraph: And the 60th Annual Quadrille Ball takes place at the Pierre.

headline: Belles of the Ball
abstract: Just ahead of fashion week, galas for amfAR and the Germanistic Society of America.
lead_paragraph: The AIDS research group amfAR  held its New York Fashion Week gala on Feb. 5 at Cipriani Wall Street. The 60th Annual Quadrille Ball, which benefits the Germanistic Society of America, was held at the Pierre on Feb. 1.

headline: How Pete Buttigieg Became the Surprise of the Iowa Caucuses
keywords: ['Primaries and Caucuses', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: Joe Biden’s organization remained weak. Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren focused on cities and college towns. Mr. Buttigieg, however, went everywhere.
lead_paragraph: OELWEIN, Iowa — Two days before the Iowa caucuses, Pete Buttigieg stopped for a town hall event at the Oelwein Coliseum, a 92-year-old music venue that in its heyday hosted the likes of Lawrence Welk and Sammy Kaye.

headline: U.S. Divided Over Chinese Drone Bans
keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: The Interior Department grounded its fleet over national security concerns. But other agencies are more worried about the impact of an all-out ban.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal agencies are split on how best to handle national security concerns surrounding popular and ubiquitous Chinese-made drones, with some policymakers chafing at more protectionist approaches.

headline: MAGA War on Architectural Diversity Weaponizes Greek Columns
keywords: ['ARCHITECTURE', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Buildings (Structures)', 'Museums', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Trump administration may impose a classical style on new federal buildings, a proposal aimed at the heart of modernism and diversity.
lead_paragraph: I was passing by the Smithsonian’s National Museum of African American History and Culture in Washington the other afternoon when the raking winter sun made the patterned, bronzed-aluminum facade glow. The building seemed to warm its patch of a frozen National Mall, alongside the chilly phalanx of gray stone behemoths, nearly all classically designed.

headline: Review: The Uninhibited Joy of Caroline Shaw’s Music
abstract: A program of her work at the Miller Theater featured So Percussion and the Attacca Quartet, fresh from a Grammy win.
lead_paragraph: What should a portrait of Caroline Shaw look like?

headline: Live Chat With the Visual Investigations Team
abstract: Want to know how the Visual Investigations team exposes crimes governments try to keep secret?
lead_paragraph: Our reporters will be taking your questions, live and on-camera, Friday Feb. 14 at 10 a.m. ET. Set a reminder at youtube.com/nytimes and submit your questions before the event.

headline: The Fastest Sesame Noodles
abstract: Ali Slagle’s take, with chicken and peanuts, can be done in 30 minutes, from start to finish.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Five Weeknight Dishes. As fervently as I believe in the power of a well-stocked pantry, there’s almost never a weeknight when I already have every single ingredient I need for dinner. Keeping fresh herbs on hand is an eternal challenge, on par with keeping track of internet passwords.

headline: Can We Please Just Blame the Virus?
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'SARS (Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome)', 'Epidemics', 'Propaganda', 'MERS (Middle East Respiratory Syndrome)', 'Censorship']
abstract: Censorship can’t stop an epidemic. Who knew.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Chinese police have exercised unusual restraint in the face of the coronavirus outbreak.

headline: When Are the Oscars? What Time? We Have Answers!
abstract: Here’s everything you need to know so you can sound like you were paying attention all along.
lead_paragraph: The 92nd Academy Awards take place Sunday. If you’ve been too busy to pay attention to the race (and who hasn’t?), here’s a primer to get you up to speed for Hollywood’s big night.

headline: House Approves Puerto Rico Aid Package, but a Path Forward Is Murky
abstract: The commonwealth has been battered by national disasters and human error, but Republicans have resisted sending the island more money.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House on Friday approved sending $4.89 billion in emergency recovery aid and additional tax relief to Puerto Rico after a series of devastating earthquakes, most likely reigniting a feud with President Trump over his objections to sending federal money to an island battered by national disasters and mismanagement.

headline: N.Y.C.F.C. Is Close to Deal to Build Stadium in the Bronx
abstract: A seven-year search for a home for the Major League Soccer team appears set to end right down the street from Yankee Stadium.
lead_paragraph: New York City F.C.’s circuitous search for a permanent home — a seven-year quest that generated frustration for the team, exasperation among its supporters and endless ridicule from rival fans in Major League Soccer — has come full circle.

headline: Buttigieg Leads Sanders in Iowa Delegates, 13-12. So, Who Won?
abstract: Mr. Buttigieg has picked up the most pledged delegates so far, but it’s early in the race: 1,990 pledged delegates are needed to secure the Democratic presidential nomination.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Former Mayor Pete Buttigieg of South Bend, Ind., has taken 13 pledged delegates from Iowa’s maligned caucuses and Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont has won 12, The Associated Press said Friday.

headline: What They Paid to Make a Baby (or 2)
abstract: Not everyone who uses I.V.F. winds up with a baby. Five families who did reveal their out-of-pocket costs.

headline: Joe Biden Shakes Up Campaign Leadership, Elevating Anita Dunn
keywords: ['Primaries and Caucuses', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Ms. Dunn, who worked in the Obama White House, is taking on a new role as Mr. Biden seeks a reset after a disappointing fourth-place finish in Iowa.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. is shaking up his campaign leadership just days ahead of the New Hampshire primary, an acknowledgment that his bid for the Democratic presidential nomination is in major trouble after a disastrous fourth-place finish in the Iowa caucuses.

headline: The Latest New Hampshire Polls: Buttigieg Looks Competitive
abstract: Three days before the New Hampshire primary, the race is looking more like a two front-runner competition between Pete Buttigieg and Bernie Sanders.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Poll Watch, our weekly look at polling data and survey research on the candidates, voters and issues that will shape the 2020 election.

headline: Review: The Met Opera Is Handel’s House in ‘Agrippina’
abstract: A vivid new production yanks this story of political power grabbing from ancient Rome into the present day.
lead_paragraph: When talk turns to whether the Metropolitan Opera should put on old works — like 1709 old — habits die hard. The story has been told for decades that intimate Baroque operas will vanish in the vast Met. Modern audiences won’t want to sit for hours through parades of static arias and confusing plots.

headline: ‘Memories Fade’: Weinstein’s Lawyers Try to Discredit Annabella Sciorra
abstract: The defense called two witnesses who cast doubt on the “Sopranos” actress’s allegation that Harvey Weinstein raped her in the 1990s.
lead_paragraph: Harvey Weinstein’s lawyers began their defense at his rape trial in Manhattan with testimony intended to discredit one of the prosecution’s strongest witnesses: the actress Annabella Sciorra, who claims Mr. Weinstein attacked her in the early 1990s.

headline: Jessica Mendoza Will Leave Mets Job
abstract: She will shift her focus to her broadcasting role for ESPN.
lead_paragraph: Jessica Mendoza, the ESPN analyst and special adviser to the Mets who was heavily criticized last month for her comments on the Astros sign-stealing scandal, has resigned from her job with the Mets. The resignation is tied to a change in her job responsibilities with ESPN.

headline: Answering Your Questions About Taylor, Mitski, Emo and More
abstract: The Popcast opens its mailbag in the first of two episodes devoted to our listeners.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times pop music team covers the full spectrum: indie rock, hip-hop, country, pure pop, Latin trap, Afrobeats and much more. But there are always questions, artists and trends left unaddressed, and Popcast listeners are excited to ask us about them.

headline: City Ballet Review: History, Rarity and an Odd, Fascinating Solo
abstract: The “Classic NYCB I” program is a gift for the faithful — completists who have seen everything and want more.
lead_paragraph: As the title for a mixed bill at New York City Ballet, “Classic NYCB I” is standard. But the program that debuted on Thursday isn’t standard or classic.

headline: How a Vegan Ends Up With Leather in Her Portfolio
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Mutual Funds', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Corporate Social Responsibility', 'Global Warming']
abstract: To invest while supporting animal welfare, socially conscious funds may support Chipotle, but not Burger King and its Impossible Whopper.
lead_paragraph: Investing well is hard enough, and introducing your personal values into the mix only compounds the confusion.

headline: Boeing Starliner Flight’s Flaws Show ‘Fundamental Problem,’ NASA Says
keywords: ['Rocket Science and Propulsion', 'Software', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Private Spaceflight']
abstract: A software glitch that could have destroyed the capsule was fixed in orbit, during an uncrewed December test flight that had already gone awry.
lead_paragraph: An uncrewed test flight of a Boeing spacecraft designed to carry NASA astronauts may have narrowly avoided catastrophic failure in December. A software error that could have resulted in loss of the spacecraft was discovered and fixed while the capsule, known as Starliner, was in orbit, and not long before it returned to Earth.

headline: Former U.A.W. Official Pleads Guilty in Corruption Scandal
abstract: Vance Pearson was once the deputy to the former union president Gary Jones, who has been portrayed as one of the orchestrators of an embezzlement scheme.
lead_paragraph: A former top official of the United Automobile Workers union pleaded guilty Friday to conspiring with fellow officials in a scheme that siphoned hundreds of thousands of dollars in members’ dues to support spending on villa rentals, lavish meals, golf clubs and golf outings.

headline: Love Letter: When Roommates Fall in Love
abstract: Plus: Going from self-loathing to self-love.
lead_paragraph: [Sign up here to receive Love Letter, a weekly newsletter about relationship highs, lows and woes, in your inbox every Friday.]

headline: The Bright Spot for Women at the Oscars
abstract: The documentary branch this year became the first to achieve gender parity since the #OscarsSoWhite hashtag pressured the Academy to diversify its membership.
lead_paragraph: — Julia Reichert, director of the documentary “American Factory”

headline: Maybe Information Actually Doesn’t Want to Be Free
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Newspapers', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Entrepreneurship', 'Venture Capital', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Start-ups']
abstract: Jessica Lessin’s online tech publication costs $399 a year and has no ads. Silicon Valley’s elite is eating it up.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Jessica Lessin thinks the biggest story of the moment — how tech is swallowing the universe — is hopelessly under-covered by the news media. The issue is “massive,” she said not long ago in her spare, cube-like office here, and “no one is paying attention.”

headline: Review: Blood Runs Too Thick in ‘Doctors Jane and Alexander’
abstract: Edward Einhorn’s playful play takes on a lot: his scientist grandfather, his aging mother and his own doubts about putting their lives onstage.
lead_paragraph: Alexander Wiener is a figure right out of a med school textbook: The award-winning physician helped discover the Rh factor in blood and advanced the fields of forensic medicine and serology. A flesh-and-blood rock star of flesh and blood, if you will. So how would one reckon with living in the shadow of such a legacy?

headline: New York to Sue Trump Administration Over Global Entry Freeze
keywords: ['Airport Security', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Federal-State Relations (US)', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Drivers Licenses', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The lawsuit will challenge the federal government’s decision to bar New Yorkers from enrolling in programs that allow travelers to skip lines at airports.
lead_paragraph: New York State officials said on Friday that they planned to sue the Trump administration over its decision this week to ban thousands of New Yorkers from enrolling in programs that allow travelers to circumvent long lines at airports and borders.

headline: Farm Bailout Paid to Brazilian Meat Processor Angers Lawmakers
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'Politics and Government', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Customs (Tariff)']
abstract: Lawmakers want to know why a Brazilian-owned company got payments from a program aimed to help American farmers weather President Trump’s trade war.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration, confident that the Chinese government will follow through on its agreement to buy more American agriculture, plans to shutter its bailout program for farmers hurt by tariffs.

headline: Chinese Car Factories Idled by Virus Raise Risks to Global Growth
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: As the coronavirus spreads, assembly lines may take longer than expected to restart, causing a chain reaction around the world.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Chinese car and car-parts factories may stay closed longer than expected because of the coronavirus, increasing the chances that assembly lines in Asia, Europe and the United States could grind to a halt because of shortages of components.

headline: A Victory in Court for Pipelines but the Debate Continues
abstract: The Federal Court of Appeal’s rejection of a challenge by Indigenous groups to the Trans Mountain pipeline won’t be the last word in the energy debate.
lead_paragraph: The decision by the Federal Court of Appeal this week to reject a challenge to the expansion of the Trans Mountain pipeline brought celebration to Alberta’s government, a sigh of relief in Ottawa and indignation to the Indigenous groups that went to court as well as to many environmentalists.

headline: The Age of Decadence
abstract: Cut the drama. The real story of the West in the 21st century is one of stalemate and stagnation.
lead_paragraph: Everyone knows that we live in a time of constant acceleration, of vertiginous change, of transformation or looming disaster everywhere you look. Partisans are girding for civil war, robots are coming for our jobs, and the news feels like a multicar pileup every time you fire up Twitter. Our pessimists see crises everywhere; our optimists insist that we’re just anxious because the world is changing faster than our primitive ape-brains can process.

headline: ‘Should We Leave?’ Life in China Under Coronavirus Lockdown
abstract: We’ve stopped changing out of our pajamas, and the days seem to melt into each other.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — It’s been two weeks since Wuhan, a city of 11 million people in central China, was placed under quarantine, and my husband and I have confined ourselves to our apartment building in Shanghai, more than 500 miles away, for the same number of days, as requested by authorities.

headline: 160 Nations Ban These Weapons. The U.S. Now Embraces Them.
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'United States International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Mines, Explosive', 'Treaties']
abstract: Cold War weapons like cluster munitions and antipersonnel mines again are approved for use, but the Pentagon seems to lack a coherent strategy for them.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration, which came into office pledging to end “endless wars,” has now embraced weapons prohibited by more than 160 countries, and is readying them for future use. Cluster bombs and antipersonnel land mines, deadly explosives known for maiming and killing civilians long after the fighting ended, have become integral to the Pentagon’s future war plans — but with little public rationale offered for where and why they would be used.

headline: Remembering Alice Mayhew, a Great Editor
abstract: A freelance writer and editor pays tribute to Ms. Mayhew, a giant in the publishing world. Also: “My broken European heart”; organ donations.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Terry DeCarlo, Gay Leader in the Wake of a Shooting, Dies at 57
abstract: After 49 people were killed at the Pulse nightclub in Orlando, Fla., in 2016, he spoke for the city’s L.G.B.T.Q. community on the national stage.
lead_paragraph: Terry DeCarlo, a spokesman for Florida’s L.G.B.T.Q. community who was thrown into the national spotlight after the mass killing in a crowded gay nightclub in Orlando in 2016, died on Jan. 27 at a hospital in Hollywood, Fla. He was 57.

headline: A Hockey Globetrotter Finds Her Showcase at Home
abstract: Alex Carpenter took her game to Canada, China and Russia after getting cut from Team U.S.A. before the 2018 Olympics. Now she is wowing in the Rivalry Series against Canada.
lead_paragraph: VANCOUVER — Early in Game 4 of the 2020 women’s hockey Rivalry Series, Team U.S.A.’s Megan Bozek skated the puck down the ice. As she entered the offensive zone, she lifted her stick horizontally and drilled it into the protective cage of Erin Ambrose, the Canadian defender who had been blocking her path to the net.

headline: Kobe Bryant Helicopter Crash Wreckage Shows No Evidence of Engine Failure
abstract: Investigators said in a preliminary report that the helicopter hurtled toward the ground at 4,000 feet per minute before crashing.
lead_paragraph: SANTA ANA, Calif. — Just before it crashed, the helicopter carrying the basketball star Kobe Bryant and eight others hurtled toward the ground at faster than 4,000 feet per minute — twice the rate the authorities had originally reported — forming a two-foot-deep crater when it slammed into a hill, investigators said in a preliminary report released on Friday.

headline: He Warned of Coronavirus. Here’s What He Told Us Before He Died.
abstract: The death of a Chinese doctor who was silenced by the police for being one of the first to warn about the coronavirus set off an outpouring of grief and anger on social media. The New York Times interviewed him last week.
lead_paragraph: The doctor who was among the first to warn about the coronavirus outbreak in late December — only to be silenced by the police —  died Friday after becoming infected with the virus, the hospital treating him reported.

headline: Stephen Joyce Dies at 87; Guarded Grandfather’s Literary Legacy
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'Wills and Estates']
abstract: The last direct descendant of the author of “Ulysses” and “Finnegans Wake” was a fierce protector of James Joyce’s estate, to the frustration of scholars.
lead_paragraph: Stephen Joyce, a grandson and last surviving direct descendant of James Joyce and the formidably rigid gatekeeper of that Irish author’s coveted literary estate, died on Jan. 23 on Île de Ré, an island resort on the west coast of France, where he lived. He was 87.

headline: Own the Recipes of Georgia O’Keeffe
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Art', 'Auctions', 'Gardens and Gardening', 'Archives and Records', 'Recipes']
abstract: For the first time, the artist’s recipe collection is going up for auction. Handwritten cards and newspaper clippings offer a peek into her well-tended domestic life.
lead_paragraph: In looping handwriting, the artist Georgia O’Keeffe sketched out a method for making chicken flautas, from rolling up chicken in tortillas to cooking a creamy green chile-spiced sauce.

headline: Germans Unnerved by Political Turmoil That Echoes Nazi Era
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Elections, Governors', 'State Legislatures', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Neo Nazi Groups']
abstract: Germans took to the streets in protest this week when the far right and Chancellor Merkel’s conservatives voted together in a local power struggle. To some, it was like “the Third Reich has been resurrected.”
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — When a popular state governor was shunted aside this week, it might have been just another local political wrangle. But not in Germany, at the current moment, with the far right resurgent.

headline: Emily Mason, Who Created Colorful Canvases, Is Dead at 87
abstract: Part of a family of artists, she was known for creating abstract works by a process she liked to call “letting a painting talk to you.”
lead_paragraph: For more than 50 years, Emily Mason, an abstract painter in a family of painters, would spend winters in Manhattan, where she had a studio in the Flatiron district, and the warmer months in Brattleboro, Vt., where she and her husband, the painter Wolf Kahn, also had a home.

headline: Justice Department Drops Antitrust Probe Against Automakers That Sided With California on Emissions
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Fuel Efficiency', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'Global Warming', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Federal-State Relations (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Justice Department has told four carmakers that they violated no laws when they negotiated a fuel economy standard with California that is more stringent than Washington’s.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department has dropped its antitrust inquiry into four automakers that had sided with California in its dispute with the Trump administration over reducing climate-warming vehicle pollution, deciding that the companies had violated no laws, according to people familiar with the matter.

headline: Our Best Valentine’s Day Recipes: Lobster, Steak, Chocolate and More
abstract: Skip the wait and the crowds. Stay home and cook for the people you love.
lead_paragraph: Whether you’re coupled or not, only gluttons for punishment go out on Valentine’s Day. Make something at home for the people you love. We have Valentine’s Day dinner ideas for everyone, whether you’re cooking a romantic dinner, a Galentine’s feast or a cozy family meal.

headline: ‘Sell the Team!’ Please, for the Sake of Mets and Knicks Fans
abstract: With the Knicks imploding and the Wilpons’ sale of the Mets to Steve Cohen collapsing, it was another classic week in New York sports dysfunction.
lead_paragraph: Something about New York sports team owners makes you despair the future of nepotism.

headline: Elizabeth Warren Has a Pete Buttigieg Problem
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Voting and Voters', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: In Iowa and New Hampshire, it’s Mr. Buttigieg — not Bernie Sanders — who has complicated Ms. Warren’s path, winning over college-educated white voters using a similar message of Democratic unity.
lead_paragraph: MERRIMACK N.H. — In the back row of an event geared toward veterans for Pete Buttigieg, the former mayor of South Bend, Ind., on Thursday, a discussion broke about one of his Democratic rivals — Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts.

headline: After Acquittal, Trump’s Attacks on Opponents
abstract: Readers criticize the president’s “uncouth” and “un-Christian” behavior at a prayer breakfast and worry about America’s future.

headline: Real Estate Groups to Challenge Ban on Broker Fees for Renters
keywords: ['Real Estate Brokers', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: A lawsuit will accuse New York State of abusing its authority in issuing a rule that has upended the industry.
lead_paragraph: Real estate agents in New York have raced this week to make sense of a new, far-reaching rule declaring that tenants no longer have to pay a broker’s fee.

headline: An Outtake From ‘The Daily’
abstract: Our team belts “One Day More” from “Les Misérables” on a car ride to a caucus site in Johnston, Iowa.
lead_paragraph: Our team belts “One Day More” from “Les Misérables” on a car ride to a caucus site in Johnston, Iowa.

headline: Coronavirus Disrupts Travel Plans Across Asia
abstract: Some tour operators, travel insurance brokers and even airline employees say they are facing growing numbers of customers who want to avoid the region.
lead_paragraph: In the midst of spreading fear over the coronavirus outbreak, travelers to Asia, even to countries far from the epicenter of the virus in China, are beginning to reconsider their plans.

headline: What’s So Great About Fake Roman Temples?
keywords: ['ARCHITECTURE', 'Buildings (Structures)', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A spectacular campaign to elevate the design of federal buildings is under threat from small-minded classicists.
lead_paragraph: The founders of this country, conscious that they were creating a new form of government, leaned heavily on the available ancient precedents. They dressed their new republic in the architecture of Greece and Rome, asserting its legitimacy with pillars and pediments.

headline: Court Throws Out Emoluments Case Brought Against Trump by Democrats
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Constitution (US)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: Legal experts had widely considered the suit to be the weakest of three lawsuits accusing the president of violating the Constitution’s emoluments clauses.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal appeals court panel threw out on Friday a lawsuit by 215 Democratic members of Congress accusing President Trump of illegally accepting benefits from foreign governments, saying that individual lawmakers cannot sue the president on behalf of the entire Congress.

headline: Setback for Kesha in Legal Battle Over Rape Claims Against Dr. Luke
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Libel and Slander', 'Music']
abstract: A judge’s ruling makes it easier for the producer Dr. Luke to prove that the singer defamed him. The judge also said Kesha wrongly claimed Dr. Luke had raped Katy Perry.
lead_paragraph: The pop singer Kesha suffered another setback this week in her long-running legal fight against Dr. Luke, her former producer, whom she accused of rape almost six years ago.

headline: Stanley Cohen, Nobelist, Dies at 97; Made Breakthrough on Cell Growth
abstract: He shared the prize with Rita Levi-Montalcini for research that opened the door to a clearer understanding of dementia, cancer and other maladies.
lead_paragraph: Stanley Cohen, a Brooklyn-born biochemist who shared the 1986 Nobel Prize in medicine for the discovery of chemicals that promote and help regulate the growth of cells — research that greatly advanced science’s understanding of cancer, dementia and other maladies — died on Wednesday in Nashville. He was 97.

headline: Saudi-Russian Alliance Is Strained as Coronavirus Saps Demand for Oil
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: OPEC is still trying to forge an agreement on new output cuts to sop up an oil glut.
lead_paragraph: An alliance between Saudi Arabia and Russia has helped prop up oil prices for the last three years. But the two big oil producers were not in perfect harmony this week, as they have tried to recalibrate production targets to cope with reduced demand from China, whose economy has been crippled by the coronavirus epidemic.

headline: ‘One Day More,’ We Sang. We Spoke Too Soon.
abstract: A dispatch from Iowa.
lead_paragraph: The Iowa caucuses were a chance for “The Daily” to try something new with our election coverage. Beyond representing the kickoff of the 2020 presidential race, they are a storied and unique style of picking a candidate — a strange exercise in democracy that’s hard to understand unless you witness it.

headline: Read the Preliminary N.T.S.B. Report About the Kobe Bryant Helicopter Crash
abstract: Federal investigators released their first written report about the crash near Calabasas, Calif., that killed the retired Los Angeles Lakers star and eight others.
lead_paragraph: The National Transportation Safety Board on Friday released its preliminary report into the helicopter crash that killed the retired basketball star Kobe Bryant, his daughter Gianna and seven other people last month.

headline: Col. Vindman and the Trumpification of the National Security Council
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: His removal is petty and vindictive. It’s also part of a bigger plan.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, the White House announced that it was transferring Lt. Col. Alexander Vindman, who testified during the House impeachment hearings, out of the National Security Council. The move is unsettling, petty and vindictive. But it’s not a surprise: The dismissal is just one part of a campaign by the national security adviser, Robert O’Brien, to trumpify one of the most powerful and important institutions in government.

headline: The National Archives Responds
abstract: The archivist of the United States objects to statements in an Op-Ed criticizing new record-keeping practices.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A New Martyr Puts a Face on China’s Deepening Coronavirus Crisis
abstract: The death of the doctor whose warnings about the coronavirus were silenced has become a potent symbol of Beijing’s failures.
lead_paragraph: WUHAN, China — More than 700 people have died. Tens of thousands are infected. Millions are living under lockdown, and the government has sought to silence complaints.

headline: Coronavirus, New Hampshire, Oscars: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

abstract: Jamison talks about Offill’s new novel, and Courtney Maum talks about “Before and After the Book Deal.”

headline: Manchester United Accuses Newspaper of Complicity in Attack on Executive’s Home
abstract: The club said The Sun had prior knowledge of a vandalism incident, and the Premier League vowed to punish abusive fans with leaguewide bans.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Premier League executives went around the room, until almost all of them had shared a story. Threats. Ugly confrontations. Physical assaults.

headline: C.D.C. and W.H.O. Offers to Help China Have Been Ignored for Weeks
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'SARS (Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome)', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Privately, Chinese doctors say they need outside expertise. But Beijing, without saying why, has shown no interest so far.

headline: Kevin Conway, ‘Elephant Man’ Actor Known for Intensity, Dies at 77
abstract: In a wide-ranging career, he appeared onstage, on TV and in films and was the voice of Mark Twain for a Ken Burns film and of an “Outer Limits” reboot.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Conway, who brought intensity to roles large and small on the screen and the stage, including memorable turns in the 1970s in the plays “When You Comin’ Back, Red Ryder?” and “The Elephant Man,” died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 77.

headline: Inundated With Flu Patients, U.S. Hospitals Brace for Coronavirus
abstract: Resources are already stretched during flu season. With so much medical equipment and drugs made in China, public health experts are anxiously watching the global supply chain.
lead_paragraph: With an intense flu season in full swing, hundreds of thousands of coughing and feverish patients have already overwhelmed emergency rooms around the United States. Now, hospitals are bracing for the potential spread of coronavirus that could bring another surge of patients.

headline: Impeachment Briefing: Impeachment’s Legacy

lead_paragraph: This newsletter spent a lot of time thinking about the politicians and officials responsible for conducting, participating in and judging the impeachment inquiry and trial. One of those officials, Lt. Col. Alexander Vindman — a member of the National Security Council — was escorted from the White House today, most likely as an act of retribution for his testimony.

He was 57.

headline: Lonely Are the Brave

The 1962 classic is about a 20th-century cowboy at mortal odds with modern life — a roaming spirit who won’t be stopped by wire fences, prison bars, search helicopters or sadistic lawmen.
